revision.text:
{{for|the epithet of the Greek god [[Dionysus]] worshiped at Aroë|Dionysus Aesymnetes}} '''Aesymnetes''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: {{lang|grc|αἰσυμνήτης}}, from {{lang|grc|αἶσα}}, ''aisa'', a "just portion", hence "a person who gives everyone their just portion") was the name of an ancient Greek elected office similar to, and sometimes indistinguishable from, [[tyrant]].<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia | last = Smith | first = William | author-link = William Smith (lexicographer) | contribution = Aesymnetes | editor-last = Smith | editor-first = William | title = [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities]] | volume = 1 | pages = 27 | publisher = | place = | year = 1870 | contribution-url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-dgra/0034.html }}</ref> The plural is ''aesymnetai''.
The title originally signified merely a judge in the heroic games, but afterwards indicated an individual who was occasionally invested voluntarily by his fellow citizens with essentially unlimited power in a Greek state. [[Aristotle]] called the office an "elective tyranny", and said that the power of the ''aesymnetai'' partook in some degree of the nature "both of kingly and tyrannical authority; since he was appointed legally and ruled over willing subjects, but at the same time was not bound by any laws in his public administration."<ref>[[Aristotle]], ''[[Politics (Aristotle)|Politics]] iii. 9. § 5, iv. 8. § 2</ref><ref>Hesych. ''s. v.''</ref>
Hence [[Theophrastus]] calls the office {{lang|grc|τυραννίς αιρετή}} ("elective tyranny"), and [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus|Dionysius]] compares it with the [[dictator]]ship at Rome.<ref name="dionysius">[[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]], v. 73</ref> It was not hereditary; but it was sometimes held for life, and at other times only until some object was accomplished, such as the reconciling of the various factions in the state. There is only one recorded instant of a person expressly receiving the title of ''Aesymnetes'': [[Pittacus of Mytilene|Pittacus]], in [[Mytilene]],<ref>{{cite book | last = Ehrenberg | first =Victor | authorlink = | title = From Solon to Socrates: Greek History and Civilization During the Sixth and Fifth Centuries B.C. | publisher =[[Routledge]] | year =1973 | location = | pages =24–25 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pkdpLMjg3lwC&pg=PA24&dq=Aesymnetes | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-415-04024-8}} </ref> who was appointed to this dignity because the state had been long torn asunder by the various factions, and who succeeded in restoring peace and order by his wise regulations and laws.<ref name="dionysius"/><ref>[[Strabo]], xiii. p. 617</ref><ref>[[Plutarch]], ''[[Solon]]'' 4</ref><ref>[[Diogenes Laërtius]], i. 75</ref><ref>Plehn, ''Lesbiaca'', pp. 4 6,48</ref>
There were, however, no doubt many other persons who ruled under this title for a while in the various states of Greece, and those law-givers bore a strong resemblance to the ''aesymnetai'', whom their fellow citizens appointed with supreme power to enact laws, as [[Draco (lawgiver)|Dracon]], [[Solon]], [[Zaleucus]] and [[Charondas]]. In some states, such as [[Cyme (Aeolis)|Cyme]] and [[Chalcedon]], it was the title borne by the regular [[magistrate]]s.
According to Aristotle, the office fell into disuse due to the risk of those who would not willingly relinquish the office, and the Greek States allowed it to disappear altogether.<ref>[[Aristotle]], ''[[Politics (Aristotle)|Politics]]'' 1285a, 31</ref><ref>{{cite book | last =[[Aristotle]] | first = | authorlink = |author2=[[William Lambert Newman]] | title =Politics | publisher =[[Harvard University Press]] | year =1902 | location = | pages =268–269 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=P9YCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA268&dq=Aesymnetes | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Elective dictatorship]] - a similar concept in [[parliamentary government]]
==References== :{{SmithDGRA|article=Aesymnetes}} {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Forms of government]] [[Category:Ancient Greek titles]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox event | title = Art of the Umbrella Movement | image = Umbrella Revolution icon 3.svg | image_size = | caption = a commonly seen logo | native_name = | native_name_lang = | date = {{start date|df=y|26 September 2014}}{{spaced ndash}}ongoing | place = Hong Kong; primarily [[Umbrella Square|Admiralty]], [[Causeway Bay]], [[Mong Kok]]; Internet | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also known as = | cause = | organisers = civil disobedience movement | first reporter = | filmed by = | participants = | outcome = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = | charges = | verdict = | convictions = | publication bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = [http://programme.rthk.hk/rthk/tv/programme.php?name=tv/theworks&d=2014-10-08&m=episode The Works] | blank_label = | blank_data = | blank1_label = | blank1_data = | blank2_label = | blank2_data = | website = {{URL|1=facebook.com/umbrellamovementartpreservation?fref=ts}} | notes = }} '''Art of the Umbrella movement''' refers to artistic works created as part of the [[Umbrella movement]] in Hong Kong which demanded democracy in the election of the territory's top leader. Most of the physical works of art are located within the three main protest sites of [[Umbrella Square|Admiralty]], [[Causeway Bay]] and [[Mong Kok]], some concepts have originated from outside Hong Kong.
Art is often held to be an integral part of activism. For the students involved in the "[[2014 Hong Kong protests|Umbrella Revolution]]", their art is a primary vehicle of expression and a method of documenting what occurs.<ref name=JournalSentinel>{{cite news |first=Mary Louise |last=Schumacher |date=6 November 2014 |title=The enchanting art of Hong Kong's Umbrella Revolution |url=http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/arts/the-enchanting-art-of-hong-kongs-umbrella-revolution-b99385524z1-281848021.html |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref> Use of the umbrella – an everyday item that protects users against the rain and the sun – by the protesters to deflect pepper spray and tear gas of the police<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://disizart.com/products/wall-prints-black-and-white-art|title=Hong Kong Police Man Stance {{!}} Wall Art Decor {{!}} Taken during the Umbrella Movement Protests in Hong Kong|last=Disizart|website=''Disizart.com''|access-date=25 November 2017}}</ref>, has given the object iconic status at a political level, symbolising resistance and the underlying social grievances.<ref name=JournalSentinel/><ref name=20141009fpol>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2014/10/09/hong_kong_protest_art|title=Hong Kong's Wild Protest Art|work=Foreign Policy}}</ref><ref name=20141007WaPo>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/10/07/photos-the-colorful-world-of-hong-kongs-protest-art/|title=Photos: The colorful world of Hong Kong’s protest art|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> The occupied streets of Hong Kong have been transformed into an extended canvas of artistic creativity.<ref name=20141008CNNprotestart>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/08/world/asia/hong-kong-protest-art/|title=Street becomes canvas for 'silent protest' in Hong Kong|author=Ivan Watson, Pamela Boykoff and Vivian Kam|date=8 October 2014|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
== Iconography == As an everyday item that protects users against the rain and the sun, the umbrella has, in the past, symbolised political weakness. In the context of the Hong Kong protests, it has been used to shield against the pepper spray and tear gas of the police, thus has become a political symbol of resistance.<ref name=JournalSentinel/><ref name=20141009fpol/><ref name=20141007WaPo/><ref name=20141001WSJcrt>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2014/10/01/hong-kong-protests-mark-twist-in-history-of-umbrella-symbolism/?mod=blog_flyover|title=Hong Kong Protests Mark Twist in History of Umbrella Symbolism|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref><ref name=20140930cnn>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/30/world/asia/objects-hong-kong-protest/|title=The symbols of Hong Kong's 'Umbrella Revolution' |author=Tim Hume and Madison Park|date=30 September 2014|publisher=CNN}}</ref> Physical umbrellas in all their guises have been used as subjects or as objects.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/> The eight-lane expanse of road freed by the occupation has been transformed into an extended canvas for artistic expression.<ref name=bbc29648459/><ref name=20141115NYTjoyce/><ref name=quartz279221>{{cite web|url=http://qz.com/279221/someone-should-preserve-hong-kongs-protest-art-before-its-too-late/|title=Someone should preserve Hong Kong's protest art before it's too late|author=Heather Timmons|work=Quartz}}</ref> One artist explained that due to the lack of physical public space in Hong Kong, people's imagination is suppressed. She added that: "When the rules that bind your action are suddenly lifted, you are given the freedom to redefine everything." Artwork featuring the form of umbrellas are in abundance.<ref name=20141006scmp/> Examples of works include umbrellas drawn on or decorated with calligraphy, balloon twisting into umbrellas, and mobiles of origami umbrellas.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=bbc29648459/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.appledaily.com.tw/realtimenews/article/new/20141026/494809/|title=佔中巧手扭出黃雨傘 嚴選「外國勢力」氣球|work=Apple Daily |language=zh}}</ref> Colette Gaiter, an Associate Professor of Art at the University of Delaware, praised the quality of the artwork as possessing "an elevated aesthetic sensibility even in the ubiquitous handwritten signs and Post-it notes".<ref name=20141007WaPo/> <gallery mode="packed" heights="160px"> Tippex artist.jpeg|Calligraphy on umbrellas Blossoms everywhere.JPG|Chalk drawing on Harcourt Road (Umb Sq) Umbrella Terms.jpg|Umbrella language </gallery>
[[Kacey Wong]], Assistant professor of Design at the Hong Kong Polytechnic University held a contest for the best logo, and received entries from all over the world.<ref name=20141007WaPo/><ref name=20140930chinarealtime/><ref name=20141106js/><ref name=artnet121249>{{cite web|url=http://news.artnet.com/art-world/artists-design-logos-for-hong-kongs-umbrella-revolution-121249|title=Best designs for the Hong Kong Umbrella Revolution|author=Zoe Li|date=3 October 2014|work=artnet News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tom-silva/branding-a-revolution_b_6017088.html|title=Branding a Revolution|work=HuffPost}}</ref><ref name=bbc29407067>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-29407067|title=How the humble umbrella became a HK protest symbol|work=''BBC News''}}</ref><ref name=20140929SCMPchow>Chow, Vivienne (29 September 2014). [http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1603858/umbrella-revolution-designers-come-logos-occupy-central-protests "Umbrella Revolution: more designs on Hong Kong’s protest movement"]. ''South China Morning Post''</ref> The competition aims to elevate awareness and generate more concern for the demand for "real universal suffrage" for Hong Kong. Wong said that use of social media such as Facebook allows for the creation of a "safe platform" for universal participation, which in turn generates awareness.<ref name=artnet121249/> Among the entries is one created by international street artist [[Invader (artist)|Invader]].{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)-->
The [[yellow ribbon]], which has been used to represent women's suffrage, was adopted early by the movement.<ref name=20140930cnn/> Activists adorned street railings and barricades with these, pinned them on shirts, and used them on Facebook profiles.<ref name=20140930cnn/><ref name=bbc29407067/> Use of the symbolic yellow crossed over into the umbrellas.<ref name=20141115NYTjoyce/><ref name=baptistgrad/>
Opening up yellow umbrellas indoors, as well as outdoors, has also become a way of sending in pro-democracy message in silence. [[Paul Zimmerman (politician)|Paul Zimmerman]], a district councillor and member of the [[Civic Party]], was an early proponent. Two days into the movement, Zimmerman opened a yellow umbrella at an indoor reception after the China National day ceremony which was attended by representatives of the PRC government.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-29446266|title=Paul Zimmerman: 'Why I took umbrella to China National Day in HK'|work=''BBC News''|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2014/10/02/red-faced-china-hong-kong-mocks-on/|title=Red (Faced) China—Hong Kong mocks on|date=2 October 2014|work=New York Post|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/photos/hong-kong-lawmaker-paul-zimmerman-talks-media-while-photo-033104464.html|title=Hong Kong lawmaker Paul Zimmerman talks to the media while holding a yellow umbrella, a symbol of the Hong Kong pro-democracy movement, at the reception to mark China's National Day in Hong Kong on October 1, 2014|date=1 October 2014|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> The graduation ceremonies of most universities in Hong Kong since October 2014 have seen attendees opening yellow umbrellas inside the hall, or graduates climbing the stage holding open umbrellas.<ref name=baptistgrad>{{cite web|url=http://cn.nytimes.com/china/20141119/c19umbrella/en-us/|title=Umbrellas Come Out at Hong Kong Graduation Ceremonies|date=19 November 2014|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name=hkustgrad>[http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=4&art_id=151193&sid=43314870&con_type=1&d_str=20141107&fc=8 "Activists bring spot of color to graduation"]. ''The Standard''. 7 November 2014</ref><ref name=scmp1631193/><ref name=citygrad>{{cite web|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20141121/-2-3479571/1.html|title=城大畢業禮續舉黃傘熱|publisher=Sina Corp}}</ref><ref name=chineseugrad>{{cite web|url=http://topick.hket.com/article/478347|title=中大畢業禮撐傘 沈祖堯：港經歷困惑時刻|work=TOPick 話題}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=11&art_id=151627&sid=43405113&con_type=1&d_str=20141121&isSearch=1&sear_year=2014 "Sung mellow with yellow as graduates earn his respect"]. ''The Standard''. 21 November 2014</ref> Dozens of supporters arrived at Hong Kong International Airport with yellow umbrellas to send off the HKFS delegation that was set to fly to Beijing on 15 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-30067035|title=Hong Kong protest leaders denied Beijing flight|work=''BBC News''}}</ref>
== Installations == A number of installations and sculptures were created at occupation sites, of which one of the largest is a patchwork hanging in the middle of [[Umbrella Square]] made of fabric taken from more than a hundred broken umbrellas which were sewn together.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=bbc29648459>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-29648459|title=In pictures: Hong Kong protest art|work=''BBC News''}}</ref><ref>Schumacher, Mary Louise (6 November 2014). [http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/arts/qa-with-charlotte-frost-about-the-umbrella-revolution-b99385857z1-281808161.html "Q&A with Charlotte Frost about the Umbrella Revolution"]. ''Journal Sentinel'' (Milwaukee).</ref> The concept was developed by Baptist University art students, to bolster the movement in the early days. A group of about ten other students stripped the fabric from umbrellas that were broken and had been stained by tear gas in the police bombardment of 28 September, and wove them together and deployed it above what is now referred to as "Umbrella Square". Tse, the project leader, hoped that the umbrellas broken by the police, fashioned into canopy, symbolises an extended physical protection for citizens that also serves as a reminder of the presence of other citizens who are behind to support, in other ways.<ref>See AJ+ video</ref> At Admiralty, large yellow umbrellas have been installed at many lamp posts; ''Happy Gadfly'' concept by mainland artist Miso Zo inspired by ''The Gadfly'', by [[Ethel Lilian Voynich]]. Made from discarded umbrellas, plastic bottles and other discarded materials, the project's originator says the installation symbolises how "They can destroy the movement, but like the fly it will come back."<ref name=20141108NYtimes/> Other sizeable installations include a pepper spray installation at Causeway Bay, a shrine to [[Kwan Yu]] at Mong Kok. <gallery mode="packed" heights="200px"> Escalator installation 2.jpg|Origami mobile and escalator eyes (Umbrella Square) Umbrella army.jpeg|Umbrella army (Umbrella Square) 2014.10.37 Hong Kong protests.JPG|Patchwork canopy from umbrella fabric (Umbrella Square) Tim Mei Avenue Umbrella Artwork 20141001.jpg|Installation on the Tim Mei Avenue roundabout (Umbrella Square) Cage installation.jpg|Birdcage (Causeway Bay) </gallery><gallery mode="packed" heights="160px"> Five umbrellas installation in Umbrella Square.jpg|Five umbrellas (Umbrella Square) Chater Heights.jpg|''I ♥ HK'' (Umbrella Square) </gallery> <gallery mode="packed" heights="160px"> Gadfly spray.jpg|Part of ''The Happy Gadfly'' (Umbrella Square) Umbrella Revolution Umbrella in Causeway Bay 20141011.jpg|Pepper spray (Causeway Bay) Kwan yu.jpg|Shrine to Guan Yu (Mong Kok) </gallery>
== Songs == "[[Do You Hear the People Sing?]]" from a musical, ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Miserables]]'', is popular with locals;<ref name=20141001guardian>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/shortcuts/2014/oct/01/hong-kong-protestor-689-democracy-cy-leung-electoral-system|title=Why are Hong Kong's protesters rallying around the number 689?|work=The Guardian}}</ref> it is sung with adapted Cantonese lyrics with a pro-democracy message.<ref name=20141106js>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/arts/the-enchanting-art-of-hong-kongs-umbrella-revolution-b99385524z1-281848021.html|title=The enchanting art of Hong Kong's Umbrella Revolution|author=Mary Louise Schumacher|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref><ref name=telegraph11130092>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/hongkong/11130092/How-a-song-from-Les-Miserables-became-Hong-Kongs-protest-anthem.html|title=How a song from Les Misérables became Hong Kong's protest anthem|date=30 September 2014|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref><ref name=NYT20141014nury/> The Chinese lyrics were written anonymously for the [[Occupy Central with Love and Peace|Occupy Central movement]] by a well-known lyricist.<ref name=20140929busweekly/><ref name=20140527sina/> In a video recording posted to YouTube in May 2014, the song named "Who Hasn't Spoke Up Yet?" ({{lang|zh-hk|問誰未發聲}}) was performed by a young girl. The video amassed 30 thousand hits in three days.<ref name=20140527sina>{{cite web|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20140527/-2-3272759/1.html|title=女童唱《問誰未發聲》支持佔中|publisher=Sina Corp|language=zh}}</ref> Three different versions were posted to the OCLP Facebook page prior to the unofficial referendum on 22 June. By 29 September, after the tear gas attack by the HK police, the video had been viewed at least 900,000 times.<ref name=20140929busweekly>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweekly.com.tw/KBlogArticle.aspx?ID=9469&pnumber=1|title=被台灣影響？小女孩主唱 香港占領中環主題曲《誰還未覺醒》|work=Business Weekly|location=Taiwan|language=zh}}</ref> At the HKIED graduation ceremony, one trumpeter played an impromptu solo of the song in support of the movement.<ref name=20141114apple>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/realtime/news/20141114/53129261|title=教院畢業禮學生撐傘奏《Do You Hear The People Sing?》 |trans-title=College graduates of the Umbrella Movement sing 'Do You Hear the People Sing' |work=Apple Daily |language=zh}}</ref>
"[[Imagine (John Lennon song)|Imagine]]" by [[John Lennon]] was adopted by suffragists following certain journals' criticism of them being "naïve dreamers". They began to quote in response the line "you may say I'm a dreamer, but I'm not the only one" from the lyrics onto banners and posters.<ref name=NYT20141014nury/>
"Raise the Umbrella" ({{lang|zh-hk|撐起雨傘}})<ref name=20141025nyt>Qin, Amy; Wong, Alan (24 October 2014). [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/25/world/asia/hong-kong-stars-face-mainland-backlash-over-support-for-protests.html "Stars Backing Hong Kong Protests Pay Price on Mainland"]. ''The New York Times''</ref><ref name=hkej>{{cite web|url=http://www2.hkej.com/instantnews/current/article/910781/%E6%9E%97%E5%A4%95%E4%BD%9C%E6%96%B0%E6%AD%8C%E3%80%8A%E6%92%90%E8%B5%B7%E9%9B%A8%E5%82%98%E3%80%8B%E9%BC%93%E5%8B%B5%E5%B9%B4%E8%BC%95%E4%BA%BA%28%E9%99%84%E6%AD%8C%E8%A9%9E%29|trans-title=Lin Xi's new song, 'Raise the Umbrella', encourages youngsters (lyrics provided)|title=林夕作新歌《撐起雨傘》鼓勵年輕人(附歌詞)|work=Hong Kong Economic Journal |language=zh}}</ref><ref name=wsj1414622180>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/chow-yun-fat-beats-jackie-chan-1414622180|title=Chow Yun-Fat Beats Jackie Chan|date=29 October 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> is specially created as encouragement to the movement by local musicians. The tune and original lyrics were written by a 25-year-old part-time musician Pan Lo ({{lang|zh-hk|羅曉彬}}) after he witnessed first hand the release of tear gas by the police. He then presented the composition to [[Denise Ho]], who wanted to take it further and suggested rewriting the lyrics to more closely fit with the mood and times. Ho then enlisted the support of other artistes, [[Anthony Wong (singer)|Anthony Wong]], [[Kay Tse]] and [[Deanie Ip]] to record the song with her after [[Lin Xi]] had reworked the lyrics.<ref name=20141006apple>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/entertainment/art/20141006/18890409|title=《撐起雨傘》作曲人 Pan鼓勵學生堅持|trans-title='Raise the Umbrella' songwriter, Pan, encourages students|work=Apple Daily|language=zh}}</ref><ref>Chan, Gloria (29 December 2014) [http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/arts-culture/article/1670491/umbrella-movement-anthem-may-become-hong-kongs-song-year "Raise the Umbrella: Occupy anthem may become Hong Kong's song of the year"]. ''South China Morning Post''</ref>
In a maiden political offering, David Cheang wrote deriding people who ignorantly or blindly opposed the Umbrella movement.<ref name=20141009FPA/><ref name=20141028-852Post/> The composition proved to be extremely popular on the internet, and was shared over 5,000 times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inmediahk.net/node/1026948|title=傾聽自己的痛苦──評佔領運動粗口歌（內文有粗口，不喜勿入）|publisher=Inmedia}}</ref> His song, "If I Call You a Stupid Dick, I’m Afraid You’d Be Mad" (話你戇鳩怕你嬲) employs [[Cantonese profanity]] in abundance, including in the title. The song lyrics start off from the perspective of a person who is fed up with the futility and inconvenience of the occupation, and then moves on to the viewpoint of another, who criticises his "friend" for polluting the earth with his bullshit.<ref name=20141009FPA> [https://foreignpolicy.com/2014/10/09/the-umbrella-movement-playlist "The Umbrella Movement Playlist"], ''Foreign Policy'' (9 October 2014)</ref> The opening lyrics managed to fool Hong Kong director [[Lee Lik-chi]] (who did not support the movement) into endorsing the song initially on his Facebook page, until the torrent of mocking posts made him delete the post.<ref name=20141028-852Post>[http://www.post852.com/%E5%8F%8D%E4%BD%94%E4%B8%AD%E6%9D%8E%E5%8A%9B%E6%8C%81%E4%B8%AD%E4%BC%8F%E3%80%80%E5%A4%A7%E8%AE%9A%E3%80%8A%E8%A9%B1%E4%BD%A0%E6%88%87x%E6%80%95%E4%BD%A0%E5%AC%B2%E3%80%8B%E6%AD%8C%E6%9B%B2/ "反佔中李力持中伏 大讚《話你戇X怕你嬲》歌曲"]. 852 Post. 28 October 2014</ref>
Another song that had been used for protests was "[[Boundless Oceans, Vast Skies]]" (also translated as "Under a Vast Sky") by Hong Kong band, [[Beyond (band)|Beyond]].<ref name=JournalSentinel/><ref name=NYT20141014nury>{{cite news |first=Nury |last=Vittachi |date=14 October 2014 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/15/opinion/hong-kongs-pop-culture-of-protest.html|title=Hong Kong's Pop Culture of Protest |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref><ref name=WSJ>{{cite news |date=1 October 2014 |first=Joyu |last=Wang |title=The Story Behind the Hong Kong Protests' Unofficial Anthem |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2014/10/01/the-story-behind-the-hong-kong-protests-unofficial-anthem/ |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref><ref name=DailyBeast>{{cite news |date=23 October 2014 |first=Brendon |last=Hong |title=Chinese Tourists Are Taking Hong Kong Protest Selfies |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/10/23/chinese-tourists-are-taking-hong-kong-protest-selfies.html |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 }}</ref>
== Caricatures == The city's leader, [[CY Leung]], elected in a small-circle election with 689 votes, is a favourite subject of caricature.<ref name=20141115NYTjoyce/> He has been represented as a wolf (or as [[Lufsig]], the Ikea soft toy), as Adolf Hitler, and as Mao Zedong.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe>Sataline, Suzanne (16 November 2014). [https://www.bostonglobe.com/ideas/2014/11/16/will-hong-kong-protest-art-saved/K5i9zT8PyR4lcAU74Dcl8O/story.html "Will Hong Kong’s protest art be saved?"] ''Boston Globe''</ref><ref name=telegraph11145726/> Alternatively, he is represented pejoratively by the numbers "689".<ref name=20141001guardian/> <gallery mode="packed" height=180px> 2014.10.25 Hong Kong protests Admiralty 27.JPG|A set of caricatures of pro-establishment figures 2014.10.47 Hong Kong protests.JPG|Caricatures of CY Leung and other posters on a central reservation in Admiralty 2014.10.56 Hong Kong protests.JPG|Caricature of CY Leung on a wooden step Mrandmshkpeople.png|Mr and Ms HK People, by Maxwell Ip </gallery>
=== "Mr and Ms. Hong Kong People" === "Mr and Little Miss Hong Kong People" is a series of caricatures that draws inspiration from Roger Hargreaves' [[Mr. Men]] series. A local graphic artist named [[Maxwell Ip]] drew a set of cartoon figures to explain the important figures behind the Umbrella movement. Originally created "just for fun", he created more once the popularity exploded, with the aim of providing suitable and politically neutral materials for parents to educate their children about the protests, and important figures involved.<ref name="scmp1631193">{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/arts-culture/article/1631193/mr-men-adaptations-inform-children-about-occupy-protests|author=Chan, Gloria|title=Mr Men adaptations inform children about the Occupy protests|date=4 November 2014|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref><ref name="20141022globalv">{{cite web|url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2014/10/22/learn-whos-who-in-hong-kongs-umbrella-revolution-with-mr-and-little-miss-hong-kong-people/|title=Learn Who's Who in Hong Kong's Umbrella Revolution With 'Mr and Little Miss Hong Kong People'|work=Global Voices}}</ref> The concept accumulated over 64,000 "likes" in just over two weeks.<ref name="scmp1631193" /> Eight hours after the creation of "Mr 689" – the nickname of Hong Kong chief executive [[CY Leung]], Ip's personal Facebook page of the character had more than 3,000 shares.<ref name="scmp1631193" /> The popularity led Ip to immediately create a public Facebook page for the characters, which are added as events unfold. In addition to the cute wolf that caricatures "Mr 689", other popular characters include "Mr Tear" (after the tear gas episode of 28 September), "Mr Chow & Mr Shum" (after the HKFS leaders [[Alex Chow]] and [[Lester Shum]]), "Mr 4 pm" (after Steve Hui of the PR section of the HK Police – who appeared on television at 4 pm daily), "Little Miss Lam Cheng" (after the Chief secretary [[Carrie Lam (politician)|Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor]])<ref name="scmp1631193" /> "Mr Hungry" (after Mok Siu Man, who started a hunger strike on 2 October that lasted 40 days) and "Little Miss Ip Cancer" (after former secretary for security [[Regina Ip]]).<ref name="20141022globalv" /> Some of the characters' names are English crossovers from Cantonese or hybrids – for example, the character of [[Joshua Wong (student activist)|Joshua Wong]] is named "Mr. G Phone", after his Chinese name.<ref name="20141022globalv" />
== Parodies of Xi Jinping and police banners == Since an image of [[Xi Jinping]], the [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of China]] (China's [[Paramount leader]] post), holding an umbrella won a top photojournalism award in China on 22 October, Xi has been parodied with a cut-out version where the umbrella has been made yellow.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=20141022wapo>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/10/22/why-a-photo-of-xi-jinping-holding-an-umbrella-won-chinas-top-photojournalism-prize/|title=Why a photo of Xi Jinping holding an umbrella won China's top photojournalism prize|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> The edited image has appeared on stickers, posters, banners and life-size and oversize banners.<ref name=bbc29817724>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-29817724|title=#BBCtrending: Chinese President's Umbrella becomes Hong Kong protest symbol|work=''BBC News''}}</ref><ref name="bbc29817724"/><ref name=20141023huff>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/23/xi-jinping-umbrella-photojournalism-prize-chinese-president_n_6035944.html|title=Photo of President Xi Jinping Holding Umbrella Wins China's Top Photojournalism Prize|work=HuffPost}}</ref><ref name=20141024global>{{cite web|url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2014/10/24/how-chinese-president-xi-jinping-and-his-yellow-umbrella-became-a-hong-kong-umbrella-revolution-meme/|title=How Chinese President Xi Jinping and His Yellow Umbrella Became a Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Protest Meme |work=Global Voices}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/node/47064|title=Hong Kong activists mark one month of 'Umbrella Movement'|work=NST Online}}</ref> ''Apple Daily'' reports that there are at least 13 cardboard cut-outs of general secretary [[Xi Jinping]] in Mong Kok, three in Causeway Bay, and one huge vertical banner depicting the image hanging from the pedestrian bridge in Admiralty. These cut-outs, many overwritten with pro-democracy or anti-communist slogans, are popular props for mainland visitors with which to take photographs.<ref name=20141105apple>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20141105/18924094|title=內地遊客 愛惡搞習總|work=Apple Daily|language=zh}}</ref> <gallery mode="packed" heights="160px"> 20141114 Hong Kong protests Admiralty bridge.jpg|To the left, Xi Jinping banner amidst others on the Harcourt Road pedestrian bridge Stop charging.JPG|Parody of police banner: "Stop Charging or We Unfurl Umbrellas" </gallery>
== ''Umbrella Man'' statue == ''Umbrella Man'' is a {{convert|10|ft|sigfig=1|adj=on}} high wooden statue created by a 22-year-old artist using the name "Milk" during the protests.<ref name=myyahoo/> The inspiration for the woodblock statue, symbolising freedom and peace, was a photograph of a suffragist holding an umbrella over a police officer to shield him from the rain.<ref name=20141008CNNprotestart/><ref name=telegraph11145726>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/hongkong/11145726/The-public-artwork-of-the-Hong-Kong-protests.html|title=The public artwork of the Hong Kong protests|date=7 October 2014|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=myyahoo>{{cite web|url=https://my.news.yahoo.com/video/interview-hong-kongs-umbrella-man-023942824.html|title=Interview With Hong Kong's 'Umbrella Man' Statue Artist|publisher=Yahoo News |location=Malaysia|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> The statue is constructed of plywood of ordinary wood tint on a metal frame.<ref name=myyahoo/> Those blocks making up the face are white, symbolising pepper spray used by the police on the suffragists; the umbrella is yellow.<ref name=telegraph11145726/> It was constructed by the artist aided by a group of ten people.<ref name=20141006scmp/>
It rapidly become an icon for the occupation movement upon its appearance on the demonstration site on 5 October 2014, and photographs of it have appeared on the front page of many newspapers and on websites around the world.<ref name=20141008CNNprotestart/><ref name=20141005bradsher>Bradsher, Keith (5 October 2014). [http://sinosphere.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/10/05/new-symbol-of-hong-kong-protests-umbrella-man/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0 "New Image of the Hong Kong Protests: 'Umbrella Man'"]. ''The New York Times''</ref> The media have compared it to the [[Goddess of Democracy]] statue erected during the [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989]].<ref name=20141008CNNprotestart/><ref name=20141006scmp>Chow, Vivienne; Siu, Phila (6 October 2014). [http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1610547/occupys-umbrella-statue-symbol-peace-says-artist?page=all "Creative awakening sparked by Occupy Central as sit-ins reclaim streets"]. ''South China Morning Post''.</ref><ref name=myyahoo/><ref name=20141005bradsher/><ref name=channelfour28255>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.channel4.com/world-news-blog/powerful-art-hong-kongs-protests/28255|title=The powerful art behind Hong Kong's protests|publisher=Channel 4|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> Since the large statue appeared, other versions emerged – a miniature woodblock version, as well as other materials, were created by others.
<gallery mode="packed" caption="Umbrella Man in Umbrella Square" heights="180px"> 2014.10.25 Hong Kong protests Admiralty 19.jpg|alt=Three-metre tall original Umbrella Man|''Umbrella Man'' statue Mini_umbrman.JPG|alt=One-metre tall wooden replica of Umbrella Man|One-metre tall ''Umbrella Man'' statue replica Umbrellaman wire.JPG|alt=Wire statues of a man holding an umbrella|Wire statues 2014.10.25 Hong Kong protests Admiralty 10.JPG|alt=Statuette of a man holding an umbrella made from wire coil|Statuette made from wire coil </gallery>
== Message boards == Numerous walls or vertical spaces within the [[Umbrella Square]] were adorned with posters and messages of encouragement during the protests.<ref name=20141027afp/> Barricades and buses that were abandoned on the streets in [[Mong Kok]] after crowds started gathering became makeshift message boards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://disizart.com/products/black-and-white-art-umbrella-movement-message-boards|title=Reporting Live From The Jungle {{!}} Wall Art Decor Prints {{!}} Taken during the Umbrella Movement Protests in Hong Kong|last=Disizart|website=''Disizart.com''|access-date=25 November 2017}}</ref> <gallery mode="packed" height="200px"> Lennon wall + Add Oil Machine.jpg|Lennon Wall with a projected message from "Add Oil Machine" AdmiraltyUmbrellaRevolution138.JPG|Close-up of post-its on the Lennon Wall AdmiraltyUmbrellaRevolution5.JPG|Road barricade serving as message board HK has choice.jpg|Message board with printed cards Umbrella message board.JPG|Girl inspects messages on a pillar Occupy Central NWFB Bus Message in Mong Kok 20140929.jpg|Bus No. 689 to Hell, a bulletin board </gallery>
=== The Lennon Wall === The [[Lennon Wall Hong Kong|Lennon Wall,]] a namesake of [[Lennon Wall|the one in Prague]], is a stretch of curved staircase in the Central Government Complex that has been covered in multi-coloured handwritten Post-it notes from supporters.<ref name="20141115NYTjoyce" /><ref name="quartz279221" /><ref name="channelfour28255" /> The messages, written mainly in Chinese and English but also other languages, include calls for genuine democracy, for [[Leung Chun-ying|CY Leung]] to step down as Chief executive, words of encouragement, and praise for the peacefulness of the protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-29479338|title=Hong Kong protests: Pleas from the protest wall|work=''BBC News''}}</ref>
=== "Stand By You: 'Add Oil' Machine" === An art collective called "Stand By You: 'Add Oil' Machine" launched a project that aimed to display messages of support to protesters. The name refers to "[[add oil]]", a term of encouragement in Chinese. The project included a website where people from all over the world could send messages, which in turn were projected onto the side of a building.<ref name="20140930chinarealtime">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2014/09/30/hong-kong-protests-inspire-creations-from-citys-artistic-community/|title=Hong Kong Protests Inspire Creations From City's Artistic Community|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> More than 30,000 messages have been received by the project from 70 countries.<ref name="rollingstone" /> The "Stand by You" project received messages of support from, among others, [[Pussy riot]] and [[Peter Gabriel]], all of whom were photographed with open umbrellas. Peter Gabriel said: "Water gets everywhere – like the will of the people".<ref name="rollingstone">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/peter-gabriel-pussy-riot-show-support-for-hong-kong-protestors-20141129|title=Peter Gabriel, Pussy Riot Show Support for Occupy Hong Kong |date=29 November 2014|work=Rolling Stone}}</ref><ref name="pussyriot">Agence France Presse, [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/peter-gabriel-pussy-riot/1501914.html "Peter Gabriel, Pussy Riot rally for Hong Kong protesters"]. Channel NewsAsia. 30 November 2014</ref>
The project received the first prize of the 2015 Freedom Flowers Foundation Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thestandnews.com/art/%E4%BD%94%E4%B8%AD%E6%89%93%E6%B0%A3%E6%A9%9F-%E7%8D%B2%E7%91%9E%E5%A3%AB%E4%BA%BA%E6%AC%8A%E8%97%9D%E8%A1%93%E9%A6%96%E7%8D%8E/|title=佔中打氣機 獲瑞士人權藝術首獎|work=Stand News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rfa.org/mandarin/Xinwen/daqiji-02242015064112.html|title=“雨伞运动”创意受国际肯定 “占中打气机”瑞士摘下桂冠|publisher=Radio Free Asia}}</ref>
== Lion Rock == Marking the expansion phase of the protest movement, a group of suffragists scaled the [[Lion Rock]], an iconic natural landmark overlooking Kowloon that carries the meaning as [[Below the Lion Rock|Hong Kong's special identity]]<ref name=20141213apple>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/realtime/news/20141213/53227385|title=【網上論壇】全城創意 遍地開花 （中大文化管理碩士課程主任 何慶基）|date=13 December 2014|work=Apple Daily |language=zh}}</ref><ref name=20141024hkshilary/><ref name=20141023wsjrealtime>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2014/10/23/pro-democracy-banner-occupies-hong-kongs-iconic-lion-rock-spawns-memes/|title=Pro-Democracy Banner Occupies Hong Kong's Iconic Lion Rock, Spawns Memes|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=23 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=rthk20141023>{{cite web|url=http://rthk.hk/rthk/news/englishnews/20141023/news_20141023_56_1048038.htm|title=Giant pro-democracy banner hung on Lion Rock|publisher=RTHK|date=23 October 2014}}</ref> The group of 14 mountaineers calling themselves "Hong Kong Spidie" ({{lang|zh|香港蜘蛛仔}}) pinned a vertical {{convert|28|by|6|m}} banner to the rock face that was visible throughout much of Kowloon.<ref name=20141024hkshilary>{{cite web|author=Hilary Wong and Kevin Cheng |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=150731&sid=43221325&con_type=3&d_str=20141024&isSearch=1&sear_year=2014 |title=Spiders get Lion's share of exposure |date=24 October 2014 |work=The Standard |accessdate=23 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024112027/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=150731&sid=43221325&con_type=3&d_str=20141024&isSearch=1&sear_year=2014 |archivedate=24 October 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20141024000149&cid=1101|title=Universal suffrage banner removed by Hong Kong gov|work=Want China Times}}</ref><ref name=dw18013822>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/hong-kong-protesters-reach-new-heights-with-democracy-banner-on-lion-rock/a-18013822|title=Hong Kong protesters reach new heights with democracy banner on Lion Rock|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=20141024scmp1623853/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/tung-chee-hwa-backs/1432774.html|title=Tung Chee-hwa backs 'genuinely democratic' Beijing model for HK vote|publisher=Channel NewsAsia}}</ref> The operation was documented in a video that was put on YouTube.<ref name=rthk20141023/><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iEQ2rj-7DDE "「香港蜘蛛仔」: 獅子山上的海闊天空 Up on the Lion Rock : Behind the Scene!!"]. YouTube video</ref> The banner, which read "I want real universal suffrage" (in Chinese), was removed the following day by fire services aided by a helicopter in an action that took approximately {{frac|1|1|2}} hours.<ref name=20141024scmp1623853>[http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1623853/giant-pro-democracy-banner-removed-hong-kongs-famous-lion-rock "Giant pro-democracy banner removed from Hong Kong's famous Lion Rock "], ''South China Morning Post'', 24 October 2014.</ref> Within days, similar banners were seen on top of [[Tai Mo Shan]] and [[Fei Ngo Shan]], placed by persons unknown – HK Spidie denied responsibility.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hk.news.yahoo.com/%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E8%9C%98%E8%9B%9B%E4%BB%94%E7%A8%B1%E9%A3%9B%E9%B5%9D%E5%B1%B1%E6%8E%9B-%E6%88%91%E8%A6%81%E7%9C%9F%E6%99%AE%E9%81%B8-%E6%A2%9D%E5%B9%85%E9%9D%9E%E4%BB%96%E5%80%91%E6%89%80%E7%82%BA-141700322.html|title=香港蜘蛛仔稱飛鵝山掛「我要真普選」條幅非他們所為|date=31 October 2014|publisher=Yahoo! |language=zh}}</ref> The banner at Fei Ngo Shan measured {{convert|5|by|20|m}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroradio.com.hk/997/News/Default.aspx?NewsID=20141101133728|title=飛鵝山和大帽山掛有爭取真普選巨型標語|publisher= 新城知訊台資訊網|language=zh}}</ref> A {{convert|9|m|adj=on}} horizontal banner was put up under cover of darkness near the radar station for the observatory at Tai Mo Shan, Hong Kong's highest peak. Upon receiving a report from a citizen at 9 am, fire services had removed the banner by noon. A government spokesman said that its removal was driven strictly by safety considerations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.singpao.com/xw/yw/201411/t20141102_534895.html|title=大帽山再現橫額被拆除|work=Sing Pao|language=zh}}</ref>
Inspired by the giant yellow banner on the face of Lion Rock, other artists have created models and parodies of the image.<ref name="20141023wsjrealtime"/><ref name=20141102scmp>"If Occupy can't come to the mountain: replica of Lion Rock unveiled", ''South China Morning Post'', 2 November 2014.</ref><ref name=20141023scmp>Clifford Lo, Peter So and Emily Tsang, [http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1622971/climbers-hang-giant-banner-lion-rock-calling-real-universal-suffrage?page=all "Pro-democracy banner hung from Lion Rock has officials scrambling"], ''South China Morning Post'', 23 October 2014.</ref> A professor at the Polytechnic University's Department of Applied Mathematics set an examination question on how to calculate the position and angle for an optimum photograph of the Lion Rock banner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20141211-polyu-professor-brings-up-lion-rock-topic-in-exam-paper/|title=PolyU professor brings up Lion Rock topic in exam paper|work=EJ Insight}}</ref> The movement also issued a challenge to put up ten banners for each one removed ({{lang|zh-hk|拆一掛十}}). Large banners have been photographed in many city roadways such as overhead pedestrian crossings in Tai Po and Kwun Tong.<ref name=20141104sina>{{cite web|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20141104/-2-3448163/1.html|title=「我要真普選」橫額攻入各區}}</ref><ref name=20141103hkej>{{cite web|url=http://www2.hkej.com/instantnews/current/article/927798/%E8%A7%80%E5%A1%98%E9%81%93%E5%A4%A9%E6%A9%8B%E7%8F%BE%E3%80%8C%E6%88%91%E8%A6%81%E7%9C%9F%E6%99%AE%E9%81%B8%E3%80%8D%E6%A9%AB%E9%A1%8D|title=觀塘道天橋現「我要真普選」橫額|work=Hong Kong Economic Journal|language=zh}}</ref> Students at a number of schools hoisted such banners on school premises – one appeared at the elite [[Diocesan Boys' School]] on the occasion of its annual school fete.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/realtime/news/20141109/53111549|title=【雨傘革命】男拔現「我要真普選」標語|work=Apple Daily|language=zh}}</ref> Police have issued public reminders that unauthorised erection of street banners may be subject to fines.<ref name=20141104sina/> <gallery mode="packed" heights="160px"> Lion Rocks Umbrella Revolution Banner 20141024.jpg|A 28-metre yellow banner which read "I want real universal suffrage" was hung on the [[Lion Rock]]. Kowloon Peak Umbrella Movement Banner 20141101.jpg|A 20-metre yellow banner hanging from Kowloon Peak Lion rock tent.JPG|Lion Rock meme drawn on tent in Admiralty </gallery>
== Vernacular == The existence of homophones in Chinese language allows great potential for wordplay that replacing characters with similar tones, or pitch patterns can effect significant changes in meaning.<ref name=gma391168>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/391168/lifestyle/peopleandevents/fun-with-puns-umbrella-terms-a-new-weapon-in-hong-kong-democracy-battle|title=Fun with puns: ‘Umbrella Terms’ a new weapon in Hong Kong democracy battle|work=GMA News Online}}</ref><ref name=20141128guardian/> Although Chinese is full of idioms, popular sayings, customs, jokes that rely on wordplay, the Beijing leadership has imposed a ban on wordplay in broadcasting as such use ostensibly breaches the law on spoken and written Chinese. Critics believe the ban is aimed at making it illegal to criticise the leadership and/or its policies in veiled manner, whilst avoiding censorship.<ref name=20141128guardian>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/28/china-media-watchdog-bans-wordplay-puns|title=China bans wordplay in attempt at pun control|author=Tania Branigan|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
Academics have noted that the protests have resulted in the unprecedented creation of new Cantonese terms that contain political puns and special idioms. There has also been a resurgence in Cantonese usage, countering the trend imposed by Beijing to expand use of [[Standard Chinese]] (aka Mandarin or Putonghua) in the place of "dialects", which is defined to include [[Cantonese]].<ref name="gma391168" />
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160px"> UmbrellaRevolution.JPG|Don't trust "left plastics" 4689 Resources.JPG|"Harcourt Road 4689" First Aid Station Umbrella Mansion.JPG|"Umbrella Mansion" Villa Hamitage.JPG|"Villa Hamitage" Govt Headquarters.JPG|Chinese characters read "really bitter headquarters" </gallery> The new lexicon of protest incorporates the term "left plastic" (左膠), a derogative term used by radicals to refer to "leftists/moderates".<ref name=quartz292835>{{cite web|url=http://qz.com/292835/hong-kongs-umbrella-movement-is-starting-to-splinter/|title=Hong Kong's Umbrella Movement is starting to splinter|author=Lily Kuo|work=Quartz}}</ref> There is also "[[gau wu]]" (鳩嗚), a vulgar homophone of a term in Mandarin which means "to shop" (購物) – the character substitution transforms the original meaning into "to occupy the streets in protest".
The encampments are referred to as "villages", road signs have been changed pointing to social change; occupiers' flimsy tents have often been given grandiose addresses such as "Umbrella Court" or "Democracy Gardens", parodying names given to luxury property developments in an increasingly unaffordable city.<ref name="gma391168" />
A glossary of the terms affiliated with the Umbrella Movement protests was created online, at umbrellaterms.hk.<ref name="gma391168" />
== The "Umbrella Man" photo == <gallery perrow="3" widths="300px" heights="190px"> File:2014 Hong Kong Umbrella Revolution as Police Attacked Peaceful Demonstrators with Tear Gas 香港渣打革命之和平抗議的香港人民以雨傘對抗發社催淚彈的港警.jpg|The photo of Umbrella Man File:港人聲援佔中抗拒警方封鎖 (15).jpg|Hong Kong Police Force decided to employ tear gas on peacefully protesting suffragists File:2014.09.27 添美道-DSC 3516 (15192486828).jpg|Protesters shielding themselves from tear gas and water cannons with umbrellas </gallery> The photo of Umbrella Man, taken 28 September 2014, depicts an unnamed male protester holding an umbrella in each hand while walking through [[tear gas]] fired by riot police.<ref>{{cite web|title=Key social moments of Hong Kong protests|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/09/30/hong-kong-protests/16473507/|work=USA Today|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> ''[[Business Insider]]'' has described the photo as iconic.<ref name=BI>{{cite web|last1=WEISENTHAL|first1=JOE|title=This Is The Iconic Hong Kong Photo The World Will Never Forget|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/umbrella-man-hong-kong-2014-9|work=Business Insider|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> It has been re-tweeted thousands of times along with multiple similar photographs tweeted during the protest,<ref>{{fr}} [https://ijsbergmagazine.com/international/article/7577-hong-kong-parapluie-revolution/ « Hong Kong : les parapluies de la liberté réprimés »], Sébastien Chatelier, Ijsberg Magazine, 1er octobre 2014</ref> which show individuals using umbrellas to protect themselves from tear gas and water. The picture's popularity and that of other pictures caused the media to dub the protests, which were also called the [[Occupy Central with Love and Peace|Occupy Central movement]], the "Umbrella Revolution".<ref>{{cite web|title=How umbrellas have become the symbol of Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/world/how-umbrellas-have-become-the-symbol-of-hong-kongs-prodemocracy-protests/story-fni0xs61-1227074588881?nk=89811c9ed70c74d554d8406ee204fdbf|work=Herald Sun|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref>
== Preservation == [[File:Visual Archive and Research Collective.jpg|thumb|Tent in Umbrella Square of the Visual Archive and Research Collective]]Two groups are involved in efforts to preserve the artwork. The Umbrella Movement Visual Archive and Research Collective, founded by Wen Yau and Sampson Wong, aims to document "how people form a community here, and how they transform the space". The collective has 10 teams of volunteers to photograph and interview those who have participated in the protests, and digitally preserve protest objects, indicate their location, and include creators' thoughts and inspirations for the works. It will create a website with interactive map and images of all the pieces.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=20141027afp/> The group is co-operating with Umbrella Movement Art Preservation, led by Meaghan McGurgan and Kacey Wong, which has made an inventory of works and their location, and will grab certain pieces before the police clear the site.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=20141115NYTjoyce/><ref name=20141115NYTjoyce>Lau, Joyce (14 November 2014). [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/15/world/asia/rescuing-protest-artwork-from-hong-kongs-streets.html "Art Spawned by Protest; Now to Make It Live On"]. ''The New York Times''.</ref><ref name=20141027afp>{{cite web|url=http://www.afp.com/en/node/2973876/|title=Saving the Umbrella Movement's art|date=27 October 2014|agency=Agence France-Presse|accessdate=21 November 2014}}</ref> The preservation groups feel it important not to denude the works of their context unless it is unavoidable.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=20141027afp/> Although many of the artists have given approval for their eventual removal, not all are agreed.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=20141027afp/> Some artists, such as the creator of ''The Happy Gadfly'', however, would like to see documented how his work is destroyed in the clearance.<ref name=20141108NYtimes>Buckley, Chris; Wong, Alan (8 December 2014). [http://sinosphere.blogs.nytimes.com//2014/12/08/a-day-among-the-protesters-tents-in-hong-kong/ "A Day Among the Protesters’ Tents in Hong Kong"]. Sinosphere, ''The New York Times''.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/389414/lifestyle/artandculture/activists-record-and-preserve-hong-kong-s-protest-artworks|title=Activists record and preserve Hong Kong's protest artworks|work=GMA News Online}}</ref> As to their storage, the groups have been rebuffed or ignored by the city's museums, most of which are government funded, due to the political nature of the work. Some galleries have volunteered to take and store them until a permanent home for them can be found.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe/><ref name=20141027afp/>
Every night over two months of occupation, volunteers made a note of objects worthy of preservation. Following weeks of discussions, a shortlist of items for salvage and preservation were selected, based on historical and aesthetic criteria.<ref name=20141214latimes>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-hong-kong-archive-20141214-story.html|title=Hong Kong protesters seek to archive their art, words for posterity|date=14 December 2014|work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> The day prior to the announced clearance of the Admiralty occupation site, 30 volunteers from the art preservation unit started salvage operations. Over 150 works and artefacts were collected from the three sites (about 100 from Admiralty, 30 from Mong Kok and 20 from Causeway Bay).<ref name=20141214mingpao>{{cite web|url=http://news.mingpao.com/pns/150%E4%BD%94%E9%A0%98%E6%96%87%E7%89%A9%E5%AD%98%E5%BA%AB%20%E7%9B%BC%E4%BF%9D%E6%AD%B7%E5%8F%B2-%E8%87%AA%E4%BF%AE%E5%AE%A4%E6%8B%9B%E7%89%8C%E8%B7%AF%E5%A3%86%E6%9C%A8%E6%A2%AF%20%20%E7%95%99%E5%BE%85%E6%AD%B8%E5%8E%9F%E4%B8%BB/web_tc/article/20141214/s00001/1418495087255|title=150佔領文物存庫 盼保歷史 – 20141214 |work=Ming Pao}}</ref> Pieces include a desk, bench, and the sign for the study area, banners, and over 20,000 messages from the Lennon Wall, which had been covered four layers deep and eventually filled 10 large bags. The project will individually scan all the messages.<ref name=20141214mingpao/> {{clear}}
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External media == {{commons category|Artwork in 2014 Hong Kong protests}} *[https://www.facebook.com/umbrellamovementartpreservation?fref=ts Facebook page], Umbrella Movement Art Preservation *[http://www.channel4.com/news/watch-live-pro-democracy-protesters-in-hong-kong "The political art behind the umbrella revolution – video"]. Channel 4. 19 October 2014 * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n22II24sdvY CNN video] on YouTube *[http://programme.rthk.hk/rthk/tv/programme.php?name=tv/theworks&d=2014-10-08&m=episode "Art in Umbrella Movement Part I"] ''The Works'', RTHK, 8 October 2014 *[https://www.facebook.com/video.php?v=471917529616426&fref=nf Facebook video from AJ+] about the creation of the umbrella canopy * [https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLe4hTFCu7-pLavOqKJq8YXJXAaGHgjROL Art of the Umbrella Movement] on YouTube {{Umbrella Movement}} * The Yellow Umbrella: A City Fable. This 2009 children's book, by Bruce Dunn, has been read through the lens of Umbrella Movement symbolism.
[[Category:The arts and politics]] [[Category:2014 Hong Kong protests]]
